content: Encaustic paint is applied to the canvas in a molten form using a heat source such as a hot palette or heat gun. It is melted and then applied to the canvas in layers, which can be carved, scraped, or textured to create different effects. The paint can also be mixed with pigments, oil paints, or other media to create different colors and textures. Once the paint has been applied, it can be fused to the canvas using heat, which creates a strong bond between the paint and the canvas. Artists often use encaustic paint to create highly textured and sculptural effects, as well as to add depth and luminosity to their paintings.
